<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Executive Compensation<a name="ExecutiveCompensation_133357"></a></font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2012 Report of the Executive Compensation and Management Resources Committee of the Board of Directors</font></b><a name="a2012ReportOfTheExecutiveCompensa_075243"></a></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Set out below is the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, which is a discussion of the Company&#146;s executive compensation programs and policies written from the perspective of how we and management view and use such programs and policies. Given the Committee&#146;s role in providing oversight to the design of those programs and policies, and in making specific compensation decisions for senior executives using those policies and programs, the Committee participated in the preparation of the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, reviewing successive drafts of the document and discussing those with management. The Committee recommended to the Board that the Compensation Discussion and Analysis be included in this Proxy Statement. We join with management in welcoming readers to examine our pay practices and in affirming the commitment of these pay practices to the long-term interests of stockholders.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 30.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sidney Taurel (chair)<br> Alain J. P. Belda<br> Andrew N. Liveris<br> W. James McNerney,&nbsp;Jr.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 30.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2012 Compensation Discussion and Analysis<a name="a2012CompensationDiscussionAndAna_075246"></a></font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Section&nbsp;1: Executive Compensation Summary</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Trust and personal responsibility in <i>all</i> relationships&#151;relationships with clients, partners, communities, fellow IBMers, and investors&#151;is a core value at IBM. Investors should have as much trust in the integrity of a company&#146;s executive compensation process as clients do in the quality of its products. A breach of this trust is unacceptable. As a part of maintaining this trust, we well understand the need for our investors&#151;not only professional fund managers and institutional investor groups, but also millions of individual investors&#151;to know how and why compensation decisions are made. We have put tremendous effort and rigor into our own executive compensation processes over many years, continually assessing and updating them to meet new voluntary criteria as well as requirements from the SEC. Investors&#151;IBM&#146;s owners&#151;want senior leaders to run the Company in a way that protects and grows their investment over the long term while appropriately managing risk. This is no simple task at any company, and at a company as large and complex as IBM, it is a particularly exciting leadership challenge. IBM holds a unique identity, based on talent, brand, global operating footprint, the size and scope of our business overall, and the size of each of our individual lines of business. Unlike those few other companies of comparable size and scale that tend to operate as holding companies of component businesses, we operate as an integrated entity across a number of significant business lines, most large enough to be among the Fortune 150 biggest companies if they were stand-alone businesses. Our unique, integrated model delivers great value to our investors and our clients, and demands a senior leadership team of unusual depth, agility and experience.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20<a name="PB_20_133459_7748"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\JMS\105540\13-1547-1\task5863813\1547-1-bi.htm',USER='105540',CD='Mar  5 05:31 2013' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p align="right" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0pt;text-align:right;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To that end,&nbsp;IBM&#146;s executive compensation practices are designed specifically to meet five key objectives:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Ensure that the interests of IBM&#146;s leaders are closely aligned with those of our investors;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Attract and retain highly qualified senior leaders who can drive a global enterprise to succeed in today&#146;s competitive marketplace;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Motivate our leaders to deliver a high degree of business performance without encouraging excessive risk taking;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Differentiate compensation so that it varies based on individual and team performance; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> Balance rewards for both short-term results and the long-term strategic decisions needed to ensure sustained business performance over time.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 17.0pt;text-indent:-12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With these goals in mind,&nbsp;IBM executives earn their compensation based on performance over three time frames:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 5.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 5.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><img width="471" height="83" src="g15471bki001.gif" alt="GRAPHIC"></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 5.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Current Year&#151;Salary and annual incentives that reflect actions and results over 12 months;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Longer-term&#151;A long-term incentive plan that reflects results over a minimum of three years, helping to ensure that current results remain sustainable; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Full Career&#151;Deferrals, retention payments and retirement accumulations help ensure today&#146;s leaders stay with IBM until their working careers end.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company considered the results of the management Say on Pay proposal presented to the stockholders for approval in 2012. In light of the support the proposal received, the Company&#146;s compensation policies and decisions, explained in detail in this CD&amp;A, continue to be focused on long-term financial performance to drive stockholder value. The Company has indicated that it will provide an advisory vote on executive compensation (Say on Pay) on an annual basis.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compensation information is disclosed in this proxy statement for both Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty and Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano. Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty succeeded Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano as President and CEO effective January 1, 2012; she assumed the Chairman&#146;s role on October&nbsp;1, 2012. Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano was Chairman until October&nbsp;1, 2012 and retired from the Company on December&nbsp;1, 2012.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Compensation Elements for Senior Leaders&#151; Focused on Performance</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The annual compensation for IBM&#146;s Senior Executives (comprised of the Chairman, the CEO and the Senior Vice Presidents (SVPs)) varies year to year based on business results and individual performance. As reflected in the charts below, for 2012, 90% of Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty&#146;s total compensation was performance based, with 27% in annual performance based incentive and 63% in long-term elements; similarly, 88% of the SVPs&#146; total compensation was performance based using the same elements. This ensures that the interests of Senior Executives are aligned with the long-term interests of stockholders.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2012 Chairman and CEO Rometty Compensation Mix*</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-weight:bold;"><img width="351" height="177" src="g15471bki002.jpg"></font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2012 SVP Compensation Mix**</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><img width="344" height="177" src="g15471bki003.jpg"></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="1" width="25%" noshade color="black" align="left"></div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">* Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty&#146;s compensation mix includes nine months as CEO and three months as Chairman &amp; CEO.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 12.25pt;text-indent:-12.25pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">** Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano is excluded from this chart. 92% of his compensation was in the form of long-term incentive, which is 100% performance based and delivered through Performance Share Units; 8% was base salary.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21<a name="PB_21_135436_7608"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\JMS\106466\13-1547-1\task5865085\1547-1-bk.htm',USER='106466',CD='Mar  5 15:10 2013' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Current Year&#146;s Performance: Salary and Annual Incentives </font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Salary</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">. Senior Executives at IBM receive a small percentage of their overall compensation in salary. In 2012, for example, as CEO, Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty earned 10% of her compensation in salary, and the SVPs earned an average of 12% of their compensation in salary.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Annual Incentive.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> The CEO and SVPs are incented through a program that sets performance targets based on their role and scope. Actual payments are driven by business performance against revenue growth, operating net income, and free cash flow targets and individual performance, as reflected in the Personal Business Commitment review process described under &#147;How and Why Compensation Decisions Are Made.&#148; Top performers earn the greatest payouts; median performers earn much smaller amounts; and the lowest performers earn no incentive payments at all. In 2012, the annual incentive earned by the CEO represented 27% of her total compensation; incentives achieved by the SVPs averaged 17% of their total compensation. Additional information about the Annual Incentive Program is outlined in Section&nbsp;2 of this CD&amp;A, &#147;Setting Performance Targets for Incentive Compensation.&#148;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Compensation.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> The SEC disclosure rules&nbsp;require that companies include certain items in the Summary Compensation Table column entitled &#147;All Other Compensation.&#148; At IBM, many of these items are available to all employees. In fact, on average, additional programs that are restricted to Senior Executive participation amount to less than 1.7% of their total compensation. IBM&#146;s security practices provide that all air travel by the Chairman and the CEO, including personal travel, be on Company aircraft. IBM does not provide any tax assistance to the Chairman or the CEO in connection with taxes incurred for personal travel by these officers on the corporate aircraft. While the cost of corporate aircraft usage varies year to year based on several external factors such as fuel costs, using corporate aircraft for all travel is a prudent step to ensure the safety of the Chairman and the CEO given the breadth of IBM&#146;s operations in over 170 countries and the realities of security risks throughout the world. Given the personal travel security practice for the Chairman and the CEO, family members periodically accompany such officers on the corporate aircraft. In accordance with tax requirements, income was imputed to Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty and Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano for personal travel by their family members on the corporate aircraft in 2012.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22<a name="PB_22_135448_8146"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='22',FILE='C:\JMS\106466\13-1547-1\task5865085\1547-1-bk.htm',USER='106466',CD='Mar  5 15:10 2013' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 5.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Longer-Term Performance: Long-Term Incentive Plan</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-term incentive plans (LTIP) have been a focal point for much of the discussion over executive compensation in the past several years. Well-designed LTIPs ensure that senior leaders hold a competitive stake in their company&#146;s financial future. At the same time, the size of the awards reflects the value that the company places on the individual executive at the time. Any gain the executives realize in the long run from the program depends on what they and their colleagues do to drive the financial performance of the company.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">IBM has two senior leadership teams: the Performance Team and the Integration&nbsp;&amp; Values Team (I&amp;VT). The Performance Team, consisting of approximately 60 senior leaders including the Chairman, the CEO and each SVP, is accountable for business performance and results and the development of cross-unit strategies. The I&amp;VT, which includes all members of the Performance Team, consists of a select group of approximately 330 executives charged with working to drive growth through integration across IBM&#146;s enterprise-wide capabilities, and align and communicate IBM&#146;s strategies and values. Under IBM&#146;s LTIP, members of the I&amp;VT may receive certain grants of IBM equity, as explained below.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Performance Share Unit (PSU) Grants.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> This portion of the LTIP focuses the I&amp;VT on delivering business performance over three years against two key financial metrics which drive long-term stockholder value &#151; operating earnings per share and free cash flow. Through this program, members of the I&amp;VT are eligible to earn a target number of shares of IBM stock at the end of a three-year performance period. The award pays out at the end of the three years depending on how well the Company performed against targets set at the beginning of the three-year period. The payouts are made in shares of stock, so the value goes up or down based on stock price performance from the beginning of the grant. Additional information about PSUs is set forth in Section&nbsp;2 of this CD&amp;A, &#147;Setting Performance Targets for Incentive Compensation.&#148;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2012, the long-term incentive grants to the Chairman, the CEO and the other members of the Performance Team were comprised entirely of PSUs. For Mrs.&nbsp;Rometty, this represents 63% of her total compensation and for Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano, this represents 92% of his total compensation, in each case assuming future performance at target. PSUs were, on average, 71% of the SVPs&#146; total compensation in 2012. In 2013, the annual long-term incentive grant for this group will again be entirely PSUs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The CEO may grant members of the I&amp;VT additional performance shares (Performance Uplift) for delivering extraordinary results. Senior Executives are not eligible for the Performance Uplift.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Stock-Based Grants.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> Our LTIP also provides for grants of other stock-based awards in addition to PSUs to focus senior leaders on delivering performance that increases the value of the Company through the growth of IBM&#146;s stock price over the long term. Although Senior Executives primarily receive only PSUs, other stock-based grants are occasionally made to this group and other executives. Other stock-based grants may include stock options, restricted stock, restricted stock units or any combination. These grants vest over time, typically over one to four years. Until vested, the grants have no cash value, except that dividend equivalents are paid on restricted stock units granted prior to January 1, 2008. For restricted stock units awarded on or after January&nbsp;1, 2008, dividend equivalents are not paid. As explained below in the &#147;2012 and 2013 Compensation Decisions for Messrs.&nbsp;Loughridge, Mills, Daniels and MacDonald,&#148; certain named executive officers received retention restricted stock unit awards in 2012. The outstanding stock-based grants for the named executive officers are shown in the 2012 Outstanding Equity Awards at Fiscal Year-End Table in this Proxy Statement.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Full Career Performance: Retention, Pension and Savings </font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Retention of our key leaders for a full career is an important element of our total compensation strategy. This is accomplished through a combination of retention payments and retirement plans.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Retention Stock-Based Grants&nbsp;&amp; Cash Awards.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> Periodically, the CEO reviews outstanding stock-based awards for the members of the I&amp;VT and other key executives. Depending on individual performance and the competitive environment for senior executive leadership talent, the CEO may recommend that the Compensation Committee approve individual retention awards in the form of restricted stock units or cash, for certain executives. The retention restricted stock unit (RRSU) grants typically vest at the end of five years, and the cash awards have a clawback (i.e., repayment clause) if an executive leaves IBM before a specified date. These awards make it more difficult for other companies to recruit IBM&#146;s top talent.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Closed Retention Plan.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> In 1995,&nbsp;IBM created a new plan to help retain, for their full careers, the caliber of senior leaders needed to turn the Company around, preserve its long-term viability, and position it for growth in the future. To discourage these leaders from joining competitors, their benefits under this retention plan would be forfeited if they left IBM prior to age 60. The approach worked, as evidenced by the Company&#146;s historic turnaround in the late 1990s, and its current position of market leadership. Because its original purpose had been met, the plan was closed to new participants in 2004. Future accruals under the plan stopped on December&nbsp;31, 2007, and the Retention Plan will not be replaced by any other plan.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23<a name="PB_23_135602_7091"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='23',FILE='C:\JMS\106466\13-1547-1\task5865085\1547-1-bk.htm',USER='106466',CD='Mar  5 15:10 2013' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Pension Plans.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> Prior to 2008,&nbsp;IBM&#146;s Senior Executives and other IBM employees in the U.S. participated in pension plans. Future accruals under the pension plans stopped on December&nbsp;31, 2007. The amount of the pension benefit under these plans is based on pay and service and is determined by the same formulas for executives and non-executives.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Savings Plan.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> IBM&#146;s Senior Executives are eligible to participate in the Company&#146;s savings plan just like any other IBM employee. Company contributions to the defined contribution plan comprise a significant portion of the &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; found in the Summary Compensation Table for the CEO and other named executive officers. The money that U.S. executives save through the IBM 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan, as for all U.S. employees, is eligible for a Company match. Effective January 1, 2008, the 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan became the only tax-qualified retirement program available to IBM&#146;s U.S. employees for future deferrals and employer contributions. Under the provisions of the plan, provided that all eligibility requirements are met,&nbsp;IBM matches a participant&#146;s own contributions dollar-for-dollar up to 6% of eligible pay for those hired before January&nbsp;1, 2005, and up to 5% for those hired on or after that date. In addition, provided that all eligibility requirements are met,&nbsp;IBM makes automatic contributions to a participant&#146;s 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan account &#151; equal to 1%, 2% or 4% of a participant&#146;s eligible pay &#151; depending on the participant&#146;s pension plan eligibility on December&nbsp;31, 2007.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Effective January&nbsp;1, 2013, Company contributions will be made once annually at the end of the year for all participants employed on December&nbsp;15 of each year. If a participant retires during the year, the individual will receive Company contributions upon retirement. Matching contributions and automatic contributions are made once a participant has completed one year of service.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Deferred Savings Plan.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> In the U.S., the Department of Labor and Internal Revenue Service also permit employees who exceed certain income thresholds to defer, on a nonqualified basis, receipt of compensation they earn. This also allows IBM to delay paying these obligations and, until they come due and are paid, to retain the cash for operating purposes. In simple terms, this deferred compensation is money earned in the past but not yet paid out. IBM does not pay guaranteed, above-market or preferential earnings on deferred compensation. For executives with long and successful careers at IBM, the deferrals can accumulate to sizeable amounts over time. Amounts deferred into IBM&#146;s nonqualified plan, the IBM Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan, are recordkeeping (notional) accounts and are not held in trust for the participants. Participants in the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan may invest their notional accounts in the primary investment options available to all employees through the 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2013, Company contributions will be made once annually at the end of the year for all participants employed on December&nbsp;15 of each year. If a participant retires during the year, the individual will receive Company contributions upon retirement. Once participants in the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan have completed one year of service, they are also eligible to receive Company matching and automatic contributions on eligible pay deferred into the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan and on money earned in excess of the Internal Revenue Code compensation limits. On an exceptional basis, the Company may agree to make a discretionary award to an executive that is credited to the executive&#146;s Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan account.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24<a name="PB_24_135622_455"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='24',FILE='C:\JMS\106466\13-1547-1\task5865085\1547-1-bk.htm',USER='106466',CD='Mar  5 15:10 2013' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">How and Why Compensation Decisions Are Made</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At any level, compensation reflects an employee&#146;s value to the business &#151; market value of skills, individual contribution and business results. To be sure we appropriately assess the value of Senior Executives,&nbsp;IBM follows an evaluation process, described here in some detail:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">1. Making Commitments</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At the beginning of each year, all IBM employees, including the CEO and SVPs, make a Personal Business Commitment (PBC) of the goals, both qualitative and quantitative, they seek to achieve that year in support of the business. These commitments are reviewed and approved by each individual&#146;s manager. The CEO&#146;s commitments are reviewed directly by the Board of Directors. As part of this process, many factors are considered, including an understanding of the business risks associated with the commitments.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2. Determining Senior Vice Presidents (SVPs) Compensation</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Evaluation of Results by the CEO</font></i></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Throughout the year, employees assess their progress against their PBCs. At year end, employees at all levels, including executives, work with their managers to evaluate their own results &#151; not only with regard to their stated goals, but in relation to how well their peers and the entire Company performed.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The self-assessments of the SVPs are reviewed by the Senior Vice President of Human Resources (SVP HR) and the CEO, who evaluate the information, along with the following:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Comparisons to market compensation levels for cash compensation and total direct compensation;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Potential for future roles within IBM; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Total compensation levels relative to internal peers before and after any recommendations.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 12.0pt;text-indent:-12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following this in-depth review and in consultation with the SVP HR, the CEO makes compensation recommendations to the Compensation Committee based on an evaluation of each SVP&#146;s performance and expectations for the coming year.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Evaluation of Results by the Compensation Committee</font></i></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation Committee decides whether to approve or adjust the CEO&#146;s recommendations for the SVPs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee evaluates all of the factors considered by the CEO and reviews compensation summaries that tally the dollar value of all compensation and related programs, including salary, annual incentive, long-term compensation, deferred compensation, retention payments and pension benefits. These summaries provide the Committee an understanding of how their decisions affect other compensation elements and the impact that separation of employment or retirement will have.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">3. Determining Compensation for the Chairman and the CEO&#151;Research, Recommendations and Review</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The chair of the Compensation Committee works directly with the Committee&#146;s compensation consultant to provide a decision-making framework for use in making a recommendation for total compensation for the Chairman and the CEO. For each officer, this framework includes a self-evaluation of performance against commitments in the year, with a self-assessment of performance against the Company&#146;s stated strategic objectives. In addition to the above, the Committee also reviews an analysis of IBM&#146;s total performance over a multi-year period and a competitive benchmark analysis provided by the Committee&#146;s outside consultant, Semler Brossy.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation Committee separately reviews all relevant information and arrives at its recommendation for total compensation for the Chairman and the CEO. In this work, the Committee is assisted by Semler Brossy.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The final pay recommendations for the Chairman and the CEO are presented to the independent directors on IBM&#146;s Board for further review, discussion and final approval.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">4. Ensuring Competitive Pay&#151;Approach to Benchmarking</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">IBM participates in several executive compensation surveys that provide general trend information and details on levels of salary, target annual incentives and long-term incentives, the relative mix of short- and long-term incentives, and mix of cash and stock-based pay. Given the battle for talent that exists in our industry, the benchmark companies that are used by the Compensation Committee to guide its decision making have included a broad range of key information technology companies, to help us identify trends in the industry. We also include companies outside our industry, with stature, size and complexity that approximate our own, in recognition of the fact that competition for senior management talent is not limited to our industry. The surveys and benchmark data are supplemented by input from the Compensation Committee&#146;s outside consultant on factors such as recent market trends. The Committee reviews and approves this list annually.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation Committee re-examined the benchmark group for 2012. After reviewing the selection criteria for the benchmark group, the Committee determined that companies from the survey participants that meet the following criteria should be included in the 2012 benchmark group:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All companies in the technology industry with revenue that exceeds $15 billion, plus</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additional</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> companies (up to two per industry) in industries other than technology, with revenue that exceeds $40 billion and that have a global complexity similar to IBM.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 12.0pt;text-indent:-12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">This group does not include companies that have participated in the U.S Government&#146;s Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP).</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25<a name="PB_25_135946_4141"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>

<tr>

<td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:33.34%;">

<td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:33.34%;">

<tr>
<td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:33.34%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ConocoPhillips</font></p>    </td>
<td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:33.34%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Johnson&nbsp;&amp;   Johnson</font></p>    </td>
<td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:33.34%;">
